Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my mom just as I sat down in the cramped break room, newsletter in hand. She wanted to know how my day was going, if I’d eaten, and if I could call her for a few minutes. I glanced at the clock—ten minutes left before I had to be back behind the counter. I’d promised myself I’d use this break to skim the latest pharmacy newsletter, to keep up with the new drugs and protocols. My supervisor had reminded us just yesterday how important it was to stay updated, and I didn’t want to fall behind. But my mom expected daily updates, and I knew she’d worry if I didn’t reply quickly. I stared at my phone, torn between the comfort of my mother’s familiar questions and the professional responsibility pressing on me. My thumb hovered over the screen, heart pounding, as I tried to decide which role needed me more in that moment.
